name: Krishna Janmashtami
title: Birth of Lord Krishna - Gokulashtami
description: Krishna Janmashtami celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna, the eighth avatar of Lord Vishnu. This joyous festival commemorates the divine incarnation who taught the world about dharma, love, and devotion.
significance: Celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna, who came to earth to establish dharma and guide humanity towards righteousness and spiritual awakening.

seo.description: Complete guide to Krishna Janmashtami festival with rituals, stories, bhajans, aartis, recipes, and celebrations. Learn the significance of Lord Krishna's birth.

sections.title: Welcome to Krishna Janmashtami
sections.content: Krishna Janmashtami is one of the most joyous Hindu festivals, celebrating the birth of Lord Krishna, the supreme personality of Godhead who descended to earth to establish dharma.

sections.title: Historical Significance
sections.content: Krishna Janmashtami has been celebrated for thousands of years and finds mention in various Hindu scriptures including the Bhagavata Purana and Mahabharata. The festival marks the divine descent of Lord Krishna.

sections.title: Famous Stories
sections.content: The birth and childhood of Lord Krishna are filled with divine stories that teach profound spiritual truths.

subsections.title: The Birth of Krishna
subsections.content: Lord Krishna was born in a prison cell in Mathura to Devaki and Vasudeva. His cruel uncle, King Kansa, had imprisoned them after a prophecy foretold that Devaki's eighth son would be his killer.

subsections.title: Miraculous Escape
subsections.content: On the night of Krishna's birth, the prison doors opened automatically and the guards fell asleep. Vasudeva carried the baby across the Yamuna River to Gokul, where he was exchanged for a baby girl and raised by Yashoda and Nanda.

sections.title: How Janmashtami is Celebrated
sections.content: Janmashtami celebrations include fasting, midnight prayers, and joyous festivities.

subsections.title: Midnight Celebrations
subsections.content: Devotees fast until midnight, which is believed to be the time of Krishna's birth. Temples are decorated, and special prayers are conducted at midnight.

subsections.title: Dahi Handi
subsections.content: The next day, Dahi Handi is celebrated, especially in Maharashtra. Young men form human pyramids to break a pot of butter (dahi) hung at a height, symbolizing Krishna's love for butter.

sections.title: Rituals and Pooja
sections.content: Janmashtami rituals include elaborate pooja ceremonies and traditional practices.

subsections.title: Abhishekam
subsections.content: The idol of baby Krishna is given a ceremonial bath (abhishekam) with milk, curd, honey, and ghee while chanting Vedic mantras.

subsections.title: Jhulan Seva
subsections.content: Devotees decorate a swing (jhula) and place the idol of Krishna on it, singing bhajans and gently swinging the deity as a sign of love and devotion.

sections.title: Janmashtami Special Foods
sections.content: Traditional foods prepared for Janmashtami reflect Krishna's favorite delicacies.

subsections.title: Krishna's Favorites
subsections.content: Makhan Mishri (butter with sugar crystals), Kheer, Malpua, and Panchamrit are Krishna's favorite foods and are offered as prasad.

subsections.title: Traditional Sweets
subsections.content: Other popular sweets include Ladoo, Barfi, and Kalakand. These are distributed among devotees as blessed prasad.

sections.title: Janmashtami Bhajans
sections.content: Devotional songs sung during Janmashtami to honor Lord Krishna.

subsections.title: Achyutam Keshavam
subsections.english:
Achyutam Keshavam Ram Narayanam
Krishna Damodaram Vasudevam Harim
Shridharam Madhavam Gopika Vallabham
subsections.meaning: This beautiful bhajan praises Lord Krishna by his various names, invoking his divine presence.

sections.title: Janmashtami Aartis
sections.content: Traditional aartis performed during Janmashtami celebrations.

subsections.title: Aarti Kunj Bihari Ki
subsections.english:
Aarti of Kunj Bihari, Shri Giridhar Krishna Murari
Aarti of Kunj Bihari
subsections.meaning: This aarti glorifies Lord Krishna as the one who wanders through the gardens of Vrindavan.
